ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provides an excellent overview of ancient history and political philosophy. It helped me develop my discussion, analysis, and writing skills.
This course provided an excellent introduction to classical political philosophy. I learned a lot about looking for connections across all the texts we read, and the importance of the authors motive.
This course helped me see the different understandings of politics that existed in western history.
I learned much about ancient history from the readings and class discussions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was a great overview class, but, as with all DS classes, there was not enough time to discuss each text in depth.
More guidance as to what exactly each author is trying to say. Sometimes it felt like we danced around their main argument without actually fleshing it out.

The primary strength is, of course, the discussions on so many great works that have passed through the ages. But personally, I wasn't expecting the heavy split between history and politics in terms of when we talked about them; it was all histories except Aristotle (which incidentally went far too fast to actually think about in depth) and then no "histories" for the rest of the semester and year. But it's a weakness of design that is somewhat necessary for the course to go temporally.

This course covered each historian or philosopher in a surprising amount of depth. Still, it was a survey course and it was jarring switching from thinker to thinker each week. In addition, we read several writers we also read in the DS philosophy course, but did not gain a dramatically improved understanding of them from the attention they received in two and not one course. I feel I would have grown more from this course if we had read Cicero and Polybius instead of spending a week and a half on Aristotle (since much of the work which inspired the later authors we read in H&P was in the Ethics and not the Politics).

Sometimes it is unclear what this course aims towards. It slips into being like philosophy at times and it can be difficult in some readings to understand the purpose of reading them is in relation to the focus of the course (ex: City of God)
More structured class discussion, more historical background on Athenian democracy and political trajectory of Rome, a clearer relation made between historiography and political philosophy
Large chunks of reading so little depth

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, you'll learn a lot, but be prepared for large amounts of reading and writing.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It was less coherent than the other DS courses, but the benefit of this is that you are better able to take your own conclusions from the course rather than the ones implicit in the ordering and structure of the reading assignments.
Its interesting but not the most rigorous in terms of historical analysis
